seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to the Collections in the Archive of Folk Culture

did.head: Collection Summary
did.physdesc: 942 photographic prints : black-and-white, color ; various sizes.

corpname.part: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract:
Papers and audiovisual materials comprising the professional archive of storyteller Connie Regan-Blake created and produced during her career from the 1960s to 2014. Includes video and audio interviews of Connie Regan-Blake; recordings of her performances and those of other storytellers at folk festivals, storytelling festivals, and media events and television programs. Regan-Blake performed at the National Storytelling Festival beginning in the 1970s and for many years as part of the storytelling duo, Folktellers, with her first cousin Barbara Freeman. The collection includes the Folktellers play,
Mountain sweet talk
, (Asheville, North Carolina's longest running theatrical production). Correspondents include Frank and Anne Warner, David McClosky, Rosa Hicks, English folklorist Katharine Briggs, Ashley Bryan, Kathryn Windham, Joan Bloss (Newberry Award winner), and Jimmy Neil Smith among many others; with photographs, programs; contracts; diaries; and artifacts.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Kaitlin Dotson with the assistance of Valda Morris.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
International Storytelling Collection (AFC 2001/008), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. Contains correspondence, ephemera, graphic images, sound and moving images of Connie Regan-Blake.
https://lccn.loc.gov/2004695174

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
Collection is open for research. Access may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Connie Regan-Blake collection (AFC 2015/003), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Storyteller Connie Regan-Blake was a key figure in the 1970s American storytelling revival. She has performed at every one of the National Storytelling Festivals, and is a founding member of what is now the International Storytelling Center. She began her career telling stories in a public library in Chattanooga, Tennessee, and later teamed up with her cousin, Barbara Freeman, to form the storytelling duo, Folktellers, from the mid-1970s through the mid-1990s. They wrote and starred in a two-woman play,
Mountain Sweet Talk
, the longest running theatrical production in Asheville, North Carolina, with seven seasons and more than 300 performances.

Regan-Blake was born January 20, 1947, in Alabama, raised in Florida, and has been a resident of Asheville for more than 30 years. After earning a Bachelor of Arts degree, in 1969 from Loyola University in New Orleans, she traveled throughout Europe. Upon her return to the U.S., she worked with Freeman at the Chattanooga Public Library as part of the childhood literacy program, M.O.R.E. (Making Our Reading Enjoyable). It was then Regan-Blake earned the nickname, "Miss Daisy."

In 1973, she and her cousin attended the first National Storytelling Festival in Jonesborough, Tennessee, where they formed lifelong friendships with many storytellers, including the founder of the Festival, Jimmy Neil Smith, Doc McConnell, and Ray and Rosa Hicks. The following year, Regan-Blake became a founding board member of the International Storytelling Center, formerly known as the National Association of the Preservation and Perpetuation of Storytelling (NAPPS) and the National Storytelling Association (NSA). She served as the artistic director of the National Storytelling Festival (1978-1983) and as the chairperson of the board of directors (1981-1984).

Regan-Blake has hosted storytelling events, workshops and coaching classes. She is the recipient of numerous awards, including the Oracle Awards Programâ€™s Lifetime Achievement Award, Circle of Excellence Award and the Distinguished National Service Award. She has received the B.B. Maurer West Virginia Folklife Scholar Award and two awards from the North Carolina Arts Council.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
Papers and audiovisual materials comprising the professional archive of storyteller Connie Regan-Blake created and produced during her career from the 1960s to 2014. Includes video and audio interviews of Connie Regan-Blake; recordings of her performances and those of other storytellers at folk festivals, storytelling festivals, and media events and television programs. Regan-Blake performed at the National Storytelling Festival beginning in the 1970s and for many years as part of the storytelling duo, Folktellers, with her first cousin Barbara Freeman. The collection includes the Folktellers play,
Mountain Sweet Talk
, (Asheville, North Carolina's longest running theatrical production). Correspondents include Frank and Anne Warner, David McClosky, Rosa Hicks, English folklorist Katharine Briggs, Ashley Bryan, Kathryn Windham, Joan Bloss (Newberry Award winner), and Jimmy Neil Smith among many others; with photographs, programs; contracts; diaries; and artifacts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: 1. Manuscripts; 2. Sound Recordings; 3. Graphic Materials; 4. Moving Images; 5. Artifacts and Ephemera. The manuscripts and graphic images are described at folder level. Emphasis was placed on arranging the materials intellectually rather than chronologically.

did.unittitle:
Spirits walk: chilling tales for teenagers and adults
,
1999

scopecontent.p: Five ghost stories: "Rag doll," "Two white horses," "Mr. Fox," "Mary Culhane," and "The veil."
Stories include "Peanut butter," "The sneakout mountain diary," "Yellow ribbon," "Jazzy three bears," "The dancing man," and "Come again in the spring."
Compilation of ghost stories: "Mary Culhane and the dead man," "The Calico coffin," "Old man all skin and bones," "How to turn into a witch," "Mr. Fox," "The wonderful wood," and "The ghoul."

Stories and songs performed by The Folktellers and friends. This includes the story,
Charlie Franklin's Truce Flag,
and the song
Beautiful Star of Bethlehem.
The album has 11 titles.
"Two white horses," "Old drye frye," "Jazzy three bears," "No news," "Mountain whippoorwills," and "Oliver Hyde's dishcloth concert."
Includes six traditional and adapted tales.
Includes six personal and adapted tales. The disc also includes a note and a signature from the storyteller, Larry Kelley.

did.unittitle:
Little, but oh my!: the story of Berte Olson, Puget Sound's first female ferryboat Captain
, 2004

scopecontent.p: Researched, written, and performed by Jill Johnson. The story is a recreation of the life of Bert Olson, who was the first woman to own her own ferryboat company.

did.unittitle:
Tea and cookies and other threatened species
, 2008

scopecontent.p: Four stories recorded live at the Charles and Myrtle's Coffeehouse, Chattanooga, Tennessee. Stories told by Jim Pfitzer.
Compilation of six storytellers telling children stories. The tellers include Donna Washington, Granny Sue Holsten, Donna Wilson, Jo Ann Dadisman, Rich Knoblich, and Suzi "Mama" Whaples.

did.unittitle:
Stories for the road and to grow on: The Folktellers' award-winning classics

scopecontent.p: A compilation of 11 stories and songs performed individually or as The Folktellers.

Tales of Appalachia: stories and chamber music
, 2004

Connie Regan-Blake tells "Rag doll" and a ghost story at the 2014 Timpanogos Storytelling Festival.

unittitle.emph: With a dog's eyes: capturing the life of Morris Frank

scopecontent.p:
An autographed copy of Bill Money's,
With a dog's eyes: capturing the life of Morris Frank.
Bill Mooney's monologue retells the story of Morris Frank who was the first person to use a Seeing Eye dog. New Jersey's public telecommunication network and New York Television of Lebanon, New Jersey.
